w:r.w:t: The Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) version 1 for Nile University of Nigeria aims to; provide a real-time update via the student portal on their attendance, develop an automated solution that enhances accountability, streamlines attendance tracking, optimizes time management for staff and student, schedules classes and exams, provides detailed reporting for academic and administrative purpose and enhance efficiency. It ensures timely and accurate data collection, integrates with the university systems, and supports analytics for decision-making. By automating these processes, the system aims to reduce manual errors, improve record accuracy, and ensure compliance with university policies and academic regulations
The scope of the Time and Attendance Management System for Nile University of Nigeria (NUN) includes the following:
Instant Notifications: Students receive immediate updates on their attendance status, including any changes or alerts.
Live Attendance Tracking: Faculty can monitor attendance in real-time, allowing for quick identification of absentees.
User -Friendly Interface: The student portal is designed for easy navigation, ensuring students can access their attendance records effortlessly.
Automated Attendance Recording: Use of technology (e.g., QR codes, biometric systems) to streamline the attendance process, reducing manual errors.
Quick Check-In/Check-Out: Students can mark their attendance swiftly, minimizing disruption during class.
Integration with Class Schedules: Attendance is automatically linked to the class timetable, ensuring accurate records.
Accessible Attendance Records: Students can view their attendance history at any time, promoting accountability.
Regular Reports: Periodic summaries of attendance are generated for students and faculty, highlighting trends and patterns.
Feedback Mechanism: Students can provide feedback on attendance policies, fostering a collaborative environment.
Engagement Metrics: Track participation levels to identify students who may be disengaged or frequently absent.
Incentives for Good Attendance: Implement rewards or recognition for students with high attendance rates to encourage commitment.
Intervention Strategies: Develop support systems for students who struggle with attendance, such as counseling or academic assistance.
Participation Logging: Record not just attendance but also active participation in class discussions and activities.
Analytics Dashboard: Provide faculty with tools to analyze participation data, helping to identify students who may need additional support.
Integration with Grading: Link participation metrics to overall academic performance, emphasizing the importance of engagement.
To Ensure Proper Schedule of Lectures:
Centralized Scheduling System: Implement a unified platform where all lecture schedules are created, managed, and accessed by both faculty and students, reducing confusion and conflicts.
Conflict Detection: Automatically identify and flag scheduling conflicts (e.g., overlapping classes or double-booked rooms) to ensure that all lectures are scheduled without issues.
Dynamic Scheduling: Allow for adjustments to be made in real-time, accommodating changes such as instructor availability, room assignments, or special events.
Student Preferences: Incorporate student input into the scheduling process, allowing them to indicate preferred times or days for classes, which can enhance attendance and engagement.

This section outlines the conventions used throughout the Software Requirements Specification (SRS) document to ensure clarity, consistency, and ease of use. By adhering to standardized formatting, labeling, and organization, the document facilitates readability and ensures accurate communication among all stakeholders.
Font Type: We have chosen a standard, readable font which is Times New Roman, typically in size 12 for body text.
Headings: We will use a hierarchical heading structure (e.g., Heading 1 for main sections,
2 for subsections) to organize content clearly. Headings will be bolded for emphasis.
Bold: Used to highlight key terms, headings, and important requirements.
Italics: Used for emphasis and to denote document titles or references.
Mono spaced Font: Used for code snippets, system messages, and commands.
All system requirements are distinctly identified using the pattern REQ [Number] (e.g., REQ001, REQ002) for reference and traceability.
Numbered Lists: Used to outline steps in processes or to organize ordered information.
Bullet Lists: Used to present unordered information or key points.
Time: Follows the 24hour format (e.g., 14:30 for 2:30 PM).
Time: Measured in hours and minutes.
Attendance: Recorded as Present (P) or Absent (A).
Sections and subsections are hierarchically numbered (e.g., 1, 1.1, 1.2) for clear structure and logical flow.
Technical terms, abbreviations, and acronyms are explained in the glossary to ensure a consistent understanding of specialized language.
or tables where appropriate to illustrate complex processes or relationships between requirements, such as the flow of attendance data.

Developers will use this document to understand the functional and non-functional requirements, system design constraints, and technical specifications necessary for building the software. They are advised to focus on the detailed requirements (Sections 3 and 4) and system architecture.

Project managers will use the document to plan, allocate resources, and monitor the progress of the software's development. They should begin with the purpose (Section 1) and scope (Section 2) to understand the goals and boundaries of the project, then review the functional requirements and priorities.

Marketing teams can leverage the document to understand the value propositions and key benefits of the software. They should focus on the system overview and benefits (Sections 1.1 and 2.1), as well as use cases that demonstrate the software's relevance to end-users.

End users, such as employees, students, and administrators, can refer to this document to gain insight into the software's functionality and usability. They are encouraged to review the use case scenarios (Section 2.3) and the functional requirements that directly impact their interactions with the system.

Quality assurance testers will utilize the document to create test cases and verify that the system meets the defined requirements. They should pay particular attention to the detailed functional requirements (Section 3), nonfunctional requirements (Section 4), and acceptance criteria.

Technical writers responsible for user manuals and guides will use the document to understand the system's features and workflows. They should focus on the functional requirements and use case scenarios (Section 2.3), which will provide the necessary information to craft comprehensive user documentation.
Document Structure and Suggested Reading Order
This document is structured to facilitate ease of understanding for all stakeholders.
Provides an overview of the purpose, scope, and audience of the document. All readers should begin here to gain context about the software.
Describes the system's goals, benefits, and key use cases. This section is particularly useful for project managers, marketing staff, and end users.
Details the functional and nonfunctional requirements of the software. Developers, testers, and documentation writers should prioritize this section.
Includes diagrams, flowcharts, and architectural overviews to illustrate how the system components interact. This section is vital for developers and technical architects.
Contains reference materials, definitions, and supplementary information. Readers seeking clarification or additional context should refer to this section.

For most readers, it is recommended to follow this sequence: Introduction Overall Description Specific Requirements System Models. Additional sections can be reviewed as needed based on roles and responsibilities.
Brief description of the Time and Attendance System

As the 21st century becomes digital, most advanced learning institutions have an integrated Time and Attendance Management system that tracks the activities of all its users. Managing an institution or any organization is like managing a big mass and keeping track of this big mass is very important for any organization. The Time and Attendance Management system is an online system capable of recording and tracking attendance to classes, work and all school visitations, its purpose is to efficiently manage and track all users.

Therefore, attendance is the top priority to keep track of the large volume of mass. But keeping attendance on track is a hectic process especially if it is done by the paper traditional method that is
currently being used in Nile university of Nigeria. But those hectic days have ended because the Attendance Management System we have come up with, will solve this issue.

This system seamlessly maintains leave management, overtime verification, tracks working-hours, class attendance, Exam attendance, school visitation (by all stakeholders including Guests) etcetera, it does this by using biometrics and a hotspot verification mechanism (class attendance). By using this system, parents can focus on their child's learning progress in school thus lowering the stress on the University by managing attendance more efficiently and accurately.

The primary purpose of the Time and Attendance Management System is to revolutionize operational efficiency by automating attendance tracking and recording while delivering real-time, actionable insights into the productivity and engagement of both employees and students. By eliminating manual inefficiencies and streamlining workflows, the system supports the universitys mission to achieve operational excellence. It ensures equitable compensation for employees by precisely tracking work hours, overtime, and attendance, while automating intricate processes such as payroll integration, faculty reward systems, scheduling, and compliance management.

For employees, the system not only guarantees fairness in wage calculation but also optimizes resource allocation and workload distribution, contributing to higher staff satisfaction and overall productivity. Meanwhile, the system significantly enhances student accountability and academic performance by providing accurate records of attendance, participation, and engagement in learning activities. This data empowers educators and administrators with the ability to monitor trends, proactively address absenteeism, and maintain equitable access to institutional resources.

The softwares intuitive interface and robust functionalities offer powerful tools for tracking and managing attendance across diverse stakeholder groups. By fostering transparency and accountability, the system strengthens trust between stakeholders while ensuring strict adherence to institutional and regulatory policies. Its analytical capabilities further enable data driven decision-making, supporting the continuous improvement of resource allocation, employee management, and student engagement strategies.

With its dual focus approach, the Time and Attendance Management System creates a seamless, efficient, and scalable solution that evolves alongside the organizations needs. By reducing administrative burdens, enhancing decision-making processes, and ensuring equity and accountability, the system lays the foundation for a sustainable, high performing academic and operational environment that benefits all stakeholders.
Benefits of a Time and Attendance Management System
Reduces time lost to manual errors commonly encountered when recording attendance or preparing payroll, ensuring precise and reliable data.
Automates time-consuming tasks such as monitoring attendance, approving or rejecting leave requests, and maintaining records.
Ensures adherence to labor laws by accurately recording working hours, breaks, and overtime, reducing the risk of violations.
Minimizes overpayments caused by time theft, inaccurate calculations, or manual processing errors, thereby reducing payroll costs.
Provides support for remote work and hybrid arrangements through features like mobile clock in and geolocation tracking.
Enables precise tracking of employee work hours, improving accountability and transparency across the organization.
Streamlines payroll operations by automating calculations and allowing integration with other HR and financial software systems.
Enhances resource planning and operational efficiency by analyzing real-time data on attendance, availability, and productivity.
Builds trust with stakeholders by maintaining honest and transparent records of employee time spent on organizational activities.
Increases overall productivity by minimizing time wasted on manual tracking and redundant processes.
Simplifies the process of tracking work hours, reducing administrative burdens and associated costs.
Decreases risks for both organizations and employees by maintaining clear, compliant, and secure records of attendance and work hours.
Adapts to evolving business needs, providing a solution that can grow with the organization as its workforce and operational demands expand
Implement advanced tools to ensure precise logging of employee work hours, including overtime and breaks, through biometric systems, mobile apps, or cloud
Automate payroll operations by integrating with existing HR and accounting systems, reducing errors and manual intervention in wage calculation.
Utilize detailed analytics to optimize staffing, reduce downtime, and allocate resources efficiently across various departments.
Foster transparency and trust by providing employees with real-time access to their attendance records, leave balances, and work schedules.
Optimize employee performance and operational workflows by eliminating bottlenecks in time tracking and attendance management.
Reduce the workload and costs associated with manual timekeeping and error correction by automating routine tasks.
Build a culture of trust by offering accurate, transparent time records and fostering accountability among employees.
Provide a robust platform that can adapt to evolving business requirements, supporting workforce expansion and new operational models without compromising efficiency.
Relation to corporate Goals and Business Strategies

The Time and Attendance Management Software directly aligns with corporate goals and business strategies by improving efficiency, ensuring compliance, and fostering accountability among staff and students. Heres how it relates:

By automating repetitive tasks such as attendance tracking, payroll processing, and resource scheduling, the software reduces administrative overhead and allows organizations to allocate resources strategically. This supports the corporate goal of maximizing productivity while minimizing waste.

Real-time insights provided by the software enable management to identify trends, optimize staffing, and improve resource allocation. These capabilities align with business strategies focused on leveraging analytics for informed decision making and continuous improvement.

By accurately tracking work hours, overtime, and attendance, the software ensures compliance with labor laws and institutional policies, reducing the risk of legal disputes or financial penalties. This supports corporate goals of maintaining ethical standards and regulatory adherence.

The system fosters a culture of trust by providing clear, accessible records for both staff and students. Transparency in time tracking and attendance management builds credibility and aligns with business strategies focused on improving organizational culture and stakeholder trust.

As organizations grow, the software scales to meet increased demands, integrating seamlessly with existing systems to support evolving business needs. This aligns with corporate goals of adaptability and long-term sustainability.

For employees, the software simplifies timekeeping and payroll processes, boosting satisfaction and morale. For students, it reinforces accountability and supports academic success. Aligning with strategies that prioritize stakeholder wellbeing, the software contributes to a positive institutional reputation.

By addressing key operational challenges and aligning with broader organizational objectives, the Time and Attendance Management Software becomes a strategic tool that drives efficiency, compliance, and engagement across the institution.
Title: IEEE Standard for Software Requirements Specifications
Name of the interviewee: Abdulsalam Nur
The Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) for Nile University of Nigeria
is a new, self-contained product which replaces conventional manual and card-based systems with attendance
management at Nile University of Nigeria. It tackles the concerns of data loss, inaccuracies, and inefficiency that arise due to outdated methods.

TAMS is an electronically automated system that employs a blend of biometric devices, mobile applications, and a hotspot verification process in capturing attendance in real time. The system works effortlessly with the existing student portal in the university to provide live updates with total transparency and accountability for all its users.

Nile University of Nigeria has experienced a steady increase in enrollment and a diversification of its academic programs, which has made the need for an efficient attendance management system more pressing. The existing methods, which may include paper-based attendance sheets or basic electronic spreadsheets, are not only cumbersome but also hinder the university's ability to maintain accurate records. These traditional methods can lead to discrepancies in attendance data, making it difficult for faculty and administration to monitor student engagement and compliance with academic policies.

The TAMS is designed to replace these outdated systems with a modern, automated solution that enhances the accuracy and efficiency of attendance tracking. By implementing this system, the university aims to provide a user-friendly interface for both students and staff, enabling them to easily check in and out, view their attendance records, and generate reports. The system will also facilitate real-time data collection and analysis, allowing for timely interventions when attendance issues arise.

The Time and Attendance Management System is not an isolated product; rather, it is a critical component of Nile Universitys broader administrative ecosystem. The integration of TAMS with other existing systems is essential for creating a cohesive and efficient operational framework.

The TAMS will interface with the SIS to access essential student data, including enrollment status, course schedules, and demographic information. This integration ensures that attendance records are accurately linked to the correct classes and students, allowing for seamless tracking of attendance across different courses. By pulling data from the SIS, the TAMS can automatically update attendance records based on class rosters, reducing the administrative burden on faculty and ensuring that attendance data is always current.

As online and hybrid learning environments become more prevalent, the TAMS will also connect with the LMS to monitor student engagement in virtual classes. This integration will allow the university to track attendance not only in physical classrooms but also in online sessions, providing a comprehensive view of student participation. By analyzing attendance data from both the
LMS and TAMS, the university can identify patterns of engagement and intervene when students are at risk of falling behind.

For staff attendance management, the TAMS will interface with the HRMS to track employee attendance and integrate this data with payroll systems. This connection will ensure that attendance records are accurately reflected in payroll calculations, thereby enhancing the efficiency of human resource operations. By automating attendance tracking for staff, the university can reduce administrative overhead and improve compliance with labor regulations.
The TAMS will feature several key interfaces that facilitate interaction with users and other systems:

The TAMS will provide both a mobile app and web-based user interface designed for ease of use by both students and staff. The UI will allow users to check in and out of classes or work, view their attendance history, and generate reports for personal or administrative use. The design will prioritize user experience, ensuring that navigation is intuitive and that users can quickly access the information they need.

A secure and robust database will serve as the backbone of the TAMS, storing all attendance data, user profiles, and system logs. The database interface will ensure that data is organized, easily retrievable, and protected against unauthorized access. Regular backups and data integrity checks will be implemented to safeguard against data loss and ensure the reliability of the system.

The TAMS will utilize restful APIs to facilitate data exchange with the SIS, LMS, and HRMS. These APIs will enable real-time synchronization of attendance data across systems, ensuring that all relevant parties have access to the most current information. For example, when a student checks in for a class, the TAMS will immediately update the SIS and LMS, reflecting the student's attendance status in all connected systems. This integration will not only enhance data accuracy but also streamline administrative processes, allowing for more efficient reporting and analysis.

The TAMS will include a reporting interface that allows administrators and faculty to generate customized reports on attendance trends, patterns, and anomalies. This feature will enable the university to analyze attendance data over time, identify areas for improvement, and make informed decisions regarding student engagement strategies and resource allocation.
Some of the major components of TAMS include:
Admin Dashboard: Administrators can manage users, set configurations, and run reports.
Employee/Student Portal: It allows users to look at attendance records and be informed.
Attendance is captured through fingerprint or facial recognition, which are secure and accurate.
It has an integrated functionality of checking in and out while verifying users against hot-spots
for attendance tracking based on proximity.
It includes storage for user details, attendance, and schedules thus ensuring data consistency and integrity.
The back-end server handles attendance data by following specific rules set by the organization. It processes this data to calculate things like work hours, absences, or late arrivals.
How the Biometric Devices and Mobile App Work Together:
Primary Capture Mechanism: Biometric devices are used in central locations, like entry points or offices, for strict attendance tracking.
The mobile app with hotspot verification allows for attendance tracking in classrooms or temporary setups.
For collecting attendance information in real time.
For updating attendance records and their accessibility to other relevant stakeholders.
TAMS is a standalone system, but it is designed to work with existing university tools, like the scheduling platform
or Human Resources systems. This means it can adapt to future needs if more functionality is required.

The Time Attendance Management System (TAMS) is a new, web-based software application designed to automate attendance tracking for educational institutions. TAMS replaces the existing manual attendance tracking system, providing a more efficient and accurate method for recording and managing student attendance.
Below is a detailed summary of the major functions that the product must perform or enable users to perform.

The system will implement a secure user authentication mechanism that allows users, including students and staff, to log in using unique credentials. This function ensures that only authorized individuals can access the system, protecting sensitive attendance data. Role-based access control will be established, allowing different functionalities based on user roles (e.g., student, faculty, administrator etc.). This ensures that users can only perform actions relevant to their responsibilities, enhancing security and data integrity.

TAMS will facilitate real-time attendance tracking, enabling students to check in and out of classes or events through various methods, such as QR codes, biometric systems (e.g., fingerprint or facial recognition), or manual entry. This function will streamline the attendance process, reducing the time spent on roll calls and minimizing errors associated with manual tracking. For staff, the system will allow them to record their attendance and manage their schedules, ensuring accurate records for payroll and performance evaluations.

The system will provide real-time updates to attendance records as users check in or out. This function ensures that attendance data is immediately available for review and reporting, allowing faculty and administration to monitor attendance trends and address issues promptly. The real-time aspect of the system will also enhance the accuracy of data, as it eliminates delays associated with manual data entry and processing.

TAMS will include robust reporting and analytics capabilities, allowing users to generate detailed attendance reports for individual students, classes, and staff over specified time periods. Administrators and faculty will be able to analyze attendance trends, patterns, and anomalies, which can help identify students who may be at risk of academic failure due to poor attendance. This function will support data-driven decision-making, enabling the university to implement targeted interventions to improve student engagement and retention.

The system will be designed to integrate seamlessly with other existing systems within the university's administrative framework. This includes synchronization with the Student Information System (SIS) to maintain accurate student records, ensuring that attendance data is linked to the correct classes and students. Additionally, TAMS will connect with the Learning Management System (LMS) to track online attendance and engagement, providing a comprehensive view of student participation in both physical and virtual learning environments. The integration with the Human Resource Management System (HRMS) will facilitate staff attendance management and ensure accurate payroll processing based on attendance records.

The system will allow users to view and update their profiles, including personal information, contact details, and attendance history. This function will empower users to take ownership of their attendance records and ensure that their information is current and accurate. For administrators, the system will provide tools to manage user accounts, including the ability to add, modify, or

The Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) for Nile University of Nigeria is designed to accommodate various user classes, each with distinct characteristics, needs, and levels of interaction with the system. Understanding these user classes is crucial for tailoring the system's functionality, user interface, and security measures to meet their specific requirements. Below are the identified user classes, along with their pertinent characteristics.
Check in/out of classes or events
Moderate; most students are familiar with basic technology and web applications.
Standard user access; can view and sign attendance, but they cannot access other users' information.
Varies; some may have extensive experience with similar systems, while others may be using such technology for the first time.

Students are the primary users of the TAMS, and their engagement with the system is critical for its success. They require a user-friendly interface that allows for quick check-ins and easy access to their attendance records. Notifications about attendance status and reminders for classes are essential to keep them informed and engaged.
Frequency of Use: Moderate to High
Check in/out of work or events
View attendance reports for their courses
Moderate; faculty and staff are generally comfortable with technology but may require training on specific system functionalities.
Higher access privileges than students; can view and manage attendance data for their classes and students
, but can only view their own attendance.
Typically holds at least a bachelors degree, often with advanced degrees.
Generally experienced in using administrative systems, but familiarity with TAMS may vary.
Faculty and staff play a crucial role in the attendance management process. They need to efficiently record attendance and access reports to monitor student engagement. The system should
provide them with tools to manage their classes and communicate with students regarding attendance-related matters.
Generate comprehensive attendance reports for institutional analysis
Monitor overall attendance trends and issues
High; administrators should have a strong understanding of database management and system administration.
Administrative access; can view and manage all user data and system configurations.
Typically holds a degree in administration, management, or a related field.
Experienced in using administrative systems and managing data.

Administrators are responsible for the overall management of the TAMS. They require advanced functionalities to oversee user accounts, generate reports, and ensure the system operates smoothly. Their role is critical for maintaining data integrity and addressing any issues that arise within the system.
Technical Expertise: Very high; should have expertise in software development, database management, and system security.
Administrative access; can access all system components for maintenance and troubleshooting.
Typically holds a degree in information technology, computer science, or a related field.
Highly experienced in IT support and system administration.

IT support staff are essential for ensuring the TAMS operates effectively. They handle technical issues, provide training to users, and maintain system security. Their expertise is crucial for the long-term success of the system.
As the primary users, their engagement and satisfaction are critical for the system's success.
Their ability to efficiently manage students attendance directly impacts their engagement and academic performance.
Responsible for overseeing the system and ensuring it meets institutional needs.
While essential for maintenance and troubleshooting, they are not daily users of the system. Their role is more supportive and technical rather than operational.

The Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) is designed to operate seamlessly within a university or school environment, incorporating diverse hardware, software, and network configurations to support real-time updates, secure data handling, and efficient user interaction. Below are the key components of the operating environment:
Processor: Minimum 2.5 GHz quadcore (Intel Xeon or equivalent) for high availability and quick response.
Memory: At least 16 GB RAM to handle large volumes of attendance data.
Storage: SSD with a minimum of 500 GB for database and application files.
Network: Gigabit Ethernet for server-side connections to support real-time data transmission and updates.
Environment: Secure, climate-controlled server rooms to ensure hardware reliability.
Devices: Desktops or laptops with at least 4 GB RAM and 2 GHz processor.
Mobile devices (smartphones or tablets) with a minimum of 2 GB RAM and Android/iOS compatibility.
Biometric devices, such as fingerprint scanners or RFID readers, for attendance tracking with secure user authentication.
Dedicated attendance devices, where applicable, for efficient classroom and office use.
Compatible with major operating systems, including Windows Server 2019 or later, and Linux distributions such as Ubuntu 20.04 LTS or CentOS 8.
Windows 10 or later, macOS 10.15 or later for desktops/laptops. Android 8.0 or later, iOS 13.0 or later for mobile devices.
Databases: Robust database management systems such as PostgreSQL 13+, MySQL 8+, or Oracle Database 19c for handling attendance data securely.
Application Server: Options include Apache Tomcat 9+, Node.js 16+, or Nginx for deployment.
Frameworks and Libraries: React.js or Angular for the frontend, with Django or Spring Boot for the backend.
RealTime Updates: Instantaneous recording and updating of attendance data accessible by teachers, administrators, and parents.
Automated Alerts: Notifications for absenteeism, late arrivals, or other anomalies sent to parents and school staff.
Integration: Seamless integration with other university or school management systems, such as Student Information Portals.
User Authentication: Secure login methods, including passwords, biometrics, or RFID cards, to ensure data integrity and security.
Scalability: Designed to handle increasing numbers of students and staff without performance degradation.
Reliability: High uptime and minimal downtime to ensure continuous operation.
Security: Strong data encryption, secure access controls, and regular security audits to protect sensitive information.
Usability: Intuitive user interfaces for ease of use by teachers, administrators, students, and parents.
Highspeed internet connection with a minimum of 10 Mbps for seamless real-time updates.
Support for VPN or secure communication protocols (e.g., HTTPS, TLS 1.3).
Technical Support: 24/7 technical support to address any issues promptly.
Regular Updates: Periodic software updates to add new features, improve performance, and enhance security.

By operating within such a robust and flexible environment, the Time and Attendance Management System ensures efficient tracking, real-time insights, and seamless communication between stakeholders, significantly improving the attendance management process.
Integration with Microsoft Teams or Google Workspace

These tools can enhance communication among staff and students, providing platforms for notifications, announcements, and collaboration on attendance-related matters. Integration with these tools can streamline workflows and improve overall efficiency.
Microsoft Power BI or Google Data Studio

These reporting tools can be utilized for data visualization and analysis of attendance metrics. They allow administrators to generate insightful reports, track trends, and make data-driven decisions regarding attendance policies and student engagement.

Implementing a robust backup strategy is essential for data integrity and recovery. Regular backups ensure that attendance records and user data are protected against data loss due to hardware failures, cyber-attacks, or accidental deletions.

These monitoring tools can be used to track system performance, resource utilization, and application health. They provide real-time insights into the system's operation, allowing IT staff to proactively address any issues that may arise.

The Time and Attendance Management System should be designed to integrate seamlessly with existing university systems, such as Student Information Systems (SIS) and Learning Management Systems (LMS). This integration will streamline processes, reduce redundancy, and enhance the overall user experience.

Supporting integration with biometric devices, such as fingerprint scanners or facial recognition systems, can enhance the accuracy of attendance tracking. This technology can help prevent proxy attendance and ensure that the system captures accurate data.
Ensuring compatibility with the university's existing network infrastructure, including Wi-Fi access points and firewalls, is crucial for smooth operation. The system should be able to function
effectively across various network conditions, providing reliable access to users throughout the campus.

The Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) is designed to operate seamlessly within a university or school environment, incorporating diverse hardware, software, and network configurations to support real-time updates, secure data handling, and efficient user interaction.
Limitations and Considerations for the Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) for Nile University of Nigeria
The TAMS must comply with the Nigerian Data Protection Regulation (NDPR) and other relevant data privacy laws, such as
the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) or the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA).
This compliance ensures the secure handling of student and staff data, including provisions for data consent, access rights, and data breach notifications.

Adherence to specific policies regarding time management and attendance tracking is essential for the successful implementation of the TAMS. This may include guidelines on attendance thresholds, reporting requirements, and data retention policies.

The system should seamlessly integrate with existing institutional platforms, including payroll software, security systems (e.g., CCTV), and Learning Management Systems (LMS) or Student Information Systems (SIS). Such integration is crucial for maintaining data consistency and streamlining administrative processes.

The server infrastructure supporting the TAMS must be capable of handling concurrent access by at least 10,000 users without downtime or performance degradation. This requirement necessitates robust server specifications and effective load balancing strategies to manage peak usage.
Limited availability of high-end biometric devices in specific departments may necessitate fallback options, such as manual attendance entries
consideration ensures that attendance tracking remains reliable even in the absence of biometric systems.

The TAMS must be compatible with existing hardware, including biometric scanners, RFID readers, and mobile devices. Ensuring compatibility will facilitate a smoother implementation and reduce additional costs for new hardware.

The system should allow offline functionality for recording attendance data, which can sync when network access is restored. This feature is particularly important in areas with unreliable internet connectivity.

The TAMS must integrate with existing biometric systems and institutional databases, ensuring compatibility with third-party applications, including payroll systems and Student Information Systems. This integration will enhance the overall functionality and user experience.

APIs should be available to enable data exchange between the Time and Attendance Management System and other applications. This will facilitate interoperability and allow for real-time data updates across systems.
Reports generated by the TAMS should be exportable in standard formats such as
CSV (Comma-Separated Values), PDF (Portable Document Format), and XLSX (Microsoft Excel Spreadsheets).
This capability will support data analysis and reporting needs for administrative staff.

The TAMS should utilize open-source or widely supported technologies to reduce licensing costs. Preferred programming languages include Python for backend development and JavaScript or Typescript for frontend development, as these languages are well-supported and have extensive libraries.

Robust database options like MySQL, PostgreSQL, or Oracle should be considered for the TAMS, ensuring ACID compliance for data integrity. This compliance is critical for maintaining accurate attendance records and user data.

Development tools and environments should support efficient coding, testing, and deployment for the Time and Attendance Management System. Tools like Docker for containerization and CI/CD pipelines for automated testing and deployment can enhance development efficiency.
The TAMS should implement multifactor authentication for administrative users to enhance security. This measure will help prevent unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Strong encryption methods, including TLS 1.3 for data in transit and AES-256 for data at rest, must be implemented in the Time and Attendance Management System to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and breaches.

Role-based access control must restrict unauthorized access to the TAMS, ensuring that users can only access data relevant to their roles. Regular security audits should be conducted to identify and address vulnerabilities.
Code for the TAMS should adhere to established standards such as PEP 8 for Python and
for JavaScript. Following these standards will improve code readability and maintainability.
Comprehensive unit and integration testing should be conducted for the Time and Attendance Management System using tools like
for Python or JUnit for Java. This practice will help ensure the reliability and functionality of the system.
Thorough documentation should be provided to facilitate future maintenance and updates by IT staff.
The system should be scalable to handle increasing user numbers and data volume over time.
It must process attendance data in real-time or near real-time to ensure timely updates and maintain high availability for multiple simultaneous users without performance issues.
The system requires secure, climate-controlled server environments to ensure reliable hardware operations.
Adequate memory and storage should support large volumes of attendance data for institutions with many users.
Reliable network protocols, such as HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure), should ensure secure data transmission.

Comprehensive documents explaining system features, workflows, and troubleshooting steps for both staff and students. Includes step-by-step guides for tasks like clocking in/out, generating reports, and managing schedules.
Integrated help menus accessible directly from the user interface. Features searchable FAQs, tooltips, and step-by-step guides for quick assistance.
Interactive walkthroughs for first-time users, covering system navigation and core functionalities. Video tutorials demonstrate advanced features like report customization and data export.
Basic setup instructions, initial configuration steps, and an overview of key features to help users start quickly.
Documents informing users about new features, enhancements, bug fixes, version history, and known issues with each software update.
Detailed technical information for system administrators and IT staff, including system architecture, installation/configuration instructions, integration details, and maintenance procedures.
Printable manuals and guides for offline use, following ISO 32000 standards for PDF.
Web based help documentation accessible through browsers and mobile devices, compliant with Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).
Embedded contextual help and tooltips directly within the system UI for real-time guidance.
Hosted on platforms like YouTube or the universitys intranet, offering
quality with closed captions for accessibility.
Step-by-step guides within the software, designed using tools like
or Intro.js for user engagement and ease of use.
Online documentation accessible via a web browser, adhering to web standards (HTML5, CSS3) and optimized for mobile compatibility.
Documentation adheres to IEEE 1063-2001 Standard for Software User Documentation to ensure consistency and usability.
Content is localized for English and any additional languages required by the institution.
Usability and accessibility standards are prioritized to enhance the user experience.
Our team assumed that third-party components, such as biometric devices, RFID readers, and software libraries, will be readily available and compatible with the TAMS.

If these components are not available or do not integrate seamlessly, it could lead to delays in development and increased costs for finding alternatives. Additionally, if the chosen components are discontinued or unsupported, it may necessitate a complete redesign of certain functionalities.
Our team assumed that users (students and staff) will accept the new system and be willing to undergo training to use it effectively.

If users resist the change or do not engage in training, it could lead to poor adoption rates and ineffective use of the system. This could result in inaccurate attendance tracking and reporting, undermining the system's intended benefits.
Our team assumed that the university's existing network infrastructure will support the TAMS, including sufficient bandwidth and reliability for real-time data processing.

the network infrastructure is inadequate, it could lead to performance issues, such as slow response times or system downtime, particularly during peak usage periods. This could frustrate users and lead to a lack of trust in the system.
Our team assumed that the TAMS will comply with all relevant regulations, such as the Nigerian Data Protection Regulation (NDPR) and any other applicable data privacy laws.

If the system does not meet these regulatory requirements, it could lead to legal issues, fines, and damage to the university's reputation. Additionally, non-compliance may require significant rework of the system to address identified gaps.
Our team assumed that the TAMS will integrate smoothly with existing university systems, such as Student Information Systems (SIS) and payroll systems.

If integration is more complex than anticipated, it could lead to delays and increased development costs. Additionally, if existing systems are outdated or poorly documented, it may complicate the integration process.
Our team assumed that user requirements will remain stable throughout the development process.

If user needs change or evolve during development, it could lead to scope creep, requiring additional resources and time to accommodate new requirements. This could also affect project timelines and budgets.
Our team assumed that the development environment (including tools, frameworks, and programming languages) will remain consistent and stable throughout the project lifecycle.

If there are changes in the development environment, such as updates to programming languages or frameworks, it could introduce compatibility issues or require retraining of the development team. This could lead to delays and increased costs.
Our team assumed that the project will have access to the necessary budget and resources (human and technical) throughout the development process.
If funding is reduced or resources become unavailable, it could lead to project delays, reduced functionality, or even project cancellation.

The TAMS may rely on third-party software components, such as libraries for data processing or reporting tools. If these components are not available or become unsupported, it could hinder the development process and require finding alternatives.

The success of the TAMS is dependent on the university's IT department for support in areas such as network infrastructure, server maintenance, and integration with existing systems. Any delays or failures in these areas could impact the project timeline and functionality.
The project relies on legal and compliance teams to provide guidance on regulatory requirements. Any changes in regulations or interpretations could necessitate adjustments to the system.

The project is dependent on ongoing communication with users and stakeholders to ensure that requirements are accurately captured and managed. Any breakdown in communication could lead to misunderstandings and misaligned expectations.
Standard buttons and functions, keyboard shortcuts and error messages
Software component for each user. Interface:

The interface design for the time and attendance management system will provide users with an. Intuitive, and efficient experience. It incorporates modern usability principles that will enhance user experience, accessibility and efficiency.
Use of same font family and typography for titles, subtitles and body text across different device.
Have uniform padding, margin and alignment. Providing a visually balanced layout.
Clear and simple visual elements for easy identification of sections
Use of universally recognizable icons (e.g., a bell for notifications, a clock for schedules, a question mark for help).
Clear separation of navigation, content and action areas in the layout.
Fixed navigation bar for easy and fast access in the desktop view.
Maintain a clean, minimalistic layout with intuitive navigation.
Breadcrumb navigation for hierarchical workflows (e.g., Home > Attendance > Mark Attendance).
Collapsible sections for extensive data, minimizing scrolling on mobile devices.
Help button should always be accessible and contextual, linking to a knowledge base or FAQs.
Logout: Accessible in the user profile dropdown in the navigation bar.
Descriptive labels for buttons and form fields.
Form validation error message for wrong email/password combination, should include descriptive text such as (
Inline error messages, display next to the relevant field in red, with explanatory text (e.g., This field is required).
Connection or loading error messages due to network interruptions.
Toast notifications for system-level errors or confirmations, with detailed explanations on hover.
main page after login to display upcoming classes and attendance record in form of a chart.
attendance percentage, and recent notifications displayed as cards.
hotspot verification and Biometric authentication icon
detailed attendance record, filters with date and subject. Accessible from student profile page.
Notification tab: Displays upcoming deadlines, class changes, or attendance warnings.
Color code attendance status. Green for present, amber for late, and red for absent.
A quick action button for instant check-in.
A drop down for subjects and course code.
display class overview in tile-based layout showing each classs name, upcoming schedule, and attendance summary. Have a
Notification tab: Displays alert for missing attendance records and upcoming classes.
Attendance check-in: QR code scanner report.

Mark attendance: Display a class roster with interactive list of registered students name and ID. Toggle buttons or checkboxes for marking attendance manually. Mark All and Reset All for efficiency. Save button with accessibility during scrolling.
Report Generation: should have filter options for class, date range and individual student. Options to download attendance record.
Bulk button for Mark All and Reset All.
Dashboard: Displays overall attendance trends, statistics, real time alerts for anomalies, and system usage metrics.
User Management: CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations for student/teacher accounts. Table layout, paginated and sorted showing user details including last login.
Search and filter bar for quick lookups.
shows log entries, actions performed, with details like user, timestamp, and action type. Provide filters for date range and action type.
Export option of audit reports for compliance and record keeping.
Navigation bar: should contain the name and logo of Nile University of Nigeria, primary navigation links and User profile dropdown.
Footer: links to privacy policy, terms of service, and system version.
Should have drop downs for course selection and autocomplete fields for ease of use.
Inline validations with error and success indicators.
Pop-ups for critical actions (e.g., Are you sure you want to delete this record?).
Include a title, detailed message, and distinct action buttons (e.g., Cancel, Confirm).
Loading state: Spinners or skeleton loaders for asynchronous operations.
Non-intrusive toast notifications for success and error messages.
Option to dismiss or view details of the notification.
Grid-based layout adapting seamlessly across device types.
The TAMS may interface with various hardware components, including:
Biometric Scanners: Devices that capture biometric data (e.g., fingerprint scanners, facial recognition cameras).
Card Readers: RFID or magnetic stripe card readers for employee identification.
Computers/Tablets: Devices used by employees and administrators to access the TAMS interface.
Network Printers: Printers for generating attendance reports, employee badges, etc.
Mobile Devices: Smartphones or tablets for mobile attendance tracking (e.g., through a mobile app).
Webcams: For facial recognition or video logging of attendance.
The logical characteristics define how the software interacts with the hardware components, including data types and control interactions.
Data Type: Biometric data (e.g., fingerprint templates, facial images).
Control Interaction: The software sends commands to the scanner to initiate the capture of biometric data and receives the processed data for verification.
Nature of Interaction: Real-time data capture and verification.
Employee ID numbers or card data.
The software sends a request to read the card, and the reader transmits the card data back to the software for processing.
Instantaneous data retrieval upon card swipe or tap.
Data Type: User input (e.g., attendance records, employee information), system logs, and reports.
Control Interaction: The software provides a user interface for data entry and displays attendance reports.
Nature of Interaction: Bidirectional data exchange for user commands and system feedback.
Data Type: Print jobs (e.g., attendance reports, employee badges).
Control Interaction: The software sends print commands and data to the printer.
Nature of Interaction: One-way communication from software to printer.
Data Type: Attendance logs, notifications, and user inputs.
Control Interaction: The mobile app communicates with the server to send attendance data and receive updates.
Nature of Interaction: Bidirectional communication over the internet or local network.
Data Type: Video streams for facial recognition.
Control Interaction: The software controls the webcam to capture images and processes them for attendance verification.
Nature of Interaction: Real-time video capture and processing.
The physical characteristics describe the hardware connections and communication protocols used for each interface.
Connection Type: USB, Serial, or Ethernet.
Communication Protocols: USB HID (Human Interface Device), TCP/IP for networked devices.
Data Format: Binary or proprietary formats for biometric data.
Data Format: ASCII or binary format for card data.
Connection Type: Ethernet or Wi-Fi for networked systems.
Communication Protocols: HTTP/HTTPS for web-based interfaces, Web Socket for real-time communication.
Data Format: JSON or XML for data exchange.
Communication Protocols: IPP (Internet Printing Protocol), LPD (Line Printer Daemon).
Data Format: PCL (Printer Command Language) or PostScript.
Connection Type: Wi-Fi or cellular data.
Communication Protocols: RESTful APIs over HTTP/HTTPS.
Data Format: JSON for API responses.
Connection Type: USB or networked (IP cameras).
Communication Protocols: UVC (USB Video Class) for USB webcams, RTSP (Real-Time Streaming Protocol) for IP cameras.
Data Format: Video stream formats (e.g., H.264, MJPEG).
To describe the connections between the Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) and other software components, we focus on the integration points, data flow, required services, and constraints
The system connects to specific software components such as databases, operating systems, tools, libraries, and third-party commercial integrations:
PostgreSQL 13+, MySQL 8+, or Oracle Database 19c handle attendance records, user data, schedules, and logs.
Incoming Data: Attendance data from biometric devices, hotspot verification or manual inputs.
Outgoing Data: Reports, alerts, and data for integration with payroll systems.
Data Sharing: Supports ACID compliance for transaction integrity during data read/write operations.
Server-Side: Windows Server 2019 or Linux (Ubuntu 20.04 LTS, CentOS 8) host the system backend.
Client-Side: Windows 10 or later, macOS 10.15 or later, Android 8.0 or later, iOS 13.0 or later support the user interface.
Backend: Developed using Python (Django) or Java (Spring Boot).
Frontend: Utilizes React.js or Angular for web applications.
Libraries for Biometric Integration: Use SDKs like DigitalPersona or SecuGen for device compatibility.
Payroll Systems: SAP, QuickBooks, or similar for syncing attendance and payroll data.
Security Software: Integration with CCTV systems or RFID-based security.
Notifications: Third-party SMS/email APIs like Twilio or SendGrid for alerts.
Biometric data from fingerprint scanners or RFID readers (used for attendance validation).
User login credentials and session details for authentication.
Manual attendance entries and adjustments by administrators.
Attendance reports exported in CSV, PDF, or XLSX formats.
Alerts/notifications for absenteeism or late arrivals sent to parents or administrators.
Data streams for integration with payroll or student management systems.
Authentication and Authorization services using protocols like OAuth 2.0.
RealTime Data Sync via WebSocket or REST APIs to ensure seamless updates across devices.
Data Encryption services for secure communication (TLS 1.3 for transit, AES256 for storage).
API Gateways for interfacing with third-party systems.
Shared data includes user profiles, attendance logs, schedules, and reports.
Communication Mechanism: Shared via REST APIs with JSON payloads or direct database integration using secure queries.

Implementation Constraint: If the system operates in a multitasking environment, global data areas must be thread safe, ensuring synchronization. Use technologies like Redis for shared memory caching to improve efficiency.
API specifications for each integration (e.g., biometric SDK, payroll system) will include endpoint definitions, request/response formats, and authentication methods.
Separate documents should outline these details for developers managing specific integrations.

The Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS) requires robust and secure communication mechanisms to facilitate data exchange between its components and external systems. Below are the detailed requirements associated with the communication functions:
Purpose: To notify users (students, staff, and administrators) about attendance related updates, such as absences, schedule changes, or system alerts.
Protocols: Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) for outgoing emails and IMAP/POP3 for receiving email responses if applicable.
Emails will be formatted in HTML for rich text and better visual presentation.
Plain text fallback for systems that do not support HTML emails.
Security: Emails will use Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) or Transport Layer Security (TLS) to encrypt communication with the mail server.
Purpose: To allow users to interact with the system through a web-based user interface (UI).
The system will use HTTP/HTTPS protocols, with all user interactions conducted over HTTPS for security.
Compatibility with modern web browsers such as Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Safari, and Microsoft Edge.
Message Formatting: JSON or XML for data exchange between the web client and the server, using RESTful APIs.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) for secure web interactions.
WebSocket Protocol for real-time updates where applicable (e.g., live attendance tracking or notifications).
Role Based Access Control (RBAC) to restrict unauthorized communication.
Purpose: To collect, display, and process attendance data through the web interface or mobile app.
Form data will be transmitted in JSON format for processing by the server.
Validation mechanisms will be implemented on both the client and server sides to ensure data integrity.
File Transfer Protocol Secure (FTPS) for securely uploading or downloading bulk data files.
Representational State Transfer (REST) APIs for interoperability between system components.
Network Time Protocol (NTP) to synchronize timestamps for attendance records across devices.
Advanced Encryption Standard (AES256) for data at rest.
Data Integrity: Hashing algorithms such as SHA256 to ensure the integrity of data transferred across the network.
Data Transfer Rates and Bandwidth Requirements
10 Mbps for server client communication to handle real-time updates.
Lower bandwidth fallback mechanisms for mobile devices in remote locations.
WebSocket connections for instant updates when attendance is recorded.
Scheduled data synchronization for noncritical updates during off-peak hours.
These requirements ensure that TAMS can deliver reliable, secure, and efficient communication across its various components and with external systems.

This feature allows the system to accurately and efficiently track attendance for staff and students using multiple methods, such as biometric devices, hotspot verification, mobile applications, and web portals. It supports real-time logging, synchronization, and reporting to ensure transparency and accountability.
Stimulus: A student places their finger on a fingerprint scanner.
Response: The system validates the fingerprint against the user database and logs the attendance.
System Response: Upon successful validation, the system marks the student as "Present" for the class and displays a confirmation message on the scanner.
Faculty Reviewing Attendance in Real Time
Stimulus: Faculty logs into the system via a web or mobile interface.
System Response: The system displays a dashboard showing the current attendance status for all ongoing classes.
Stimulus: Faculty selects a specific class to view the detailed attendance list.
System Response: The system retrieves and displays the list of students marked as "Present," "Absent," or "Late."
Stimulus: The system detects a pattern of absences for a particular student.
System Response: Sends an automated alert to the students registered email and notifies faculty of the attendance anomaly.
Stimulus: A user logs in through the mobile app and selects the "Clock In" button.
Response: The system verifies credentials, records the time and location, and updates the attendance database.
Stimulus: A user logs into the web portal and marks their attendance.
Response: The system timestamps the action, records the users IP address, and updates the database.
Stimulus: An administrator generates an attendance report for a specific date range.
Response: The system queries the database and produces the report in the requested format (e.g., PDF, CSV).
Stimulus: A user forgets to log attendance and requests a notification.
Response: The system sends a notification via email or mobile app, reminding them to log their attendance.
REQ1: The system must support attendance logging via biometric devices, hotspot verification, mobile applications, and web portals.
REQ2: The system must validate user credentials (e.g., fingerprints, passwords, or biometrics) before logging attendance.
REQ3: The system must record timestamps, locations (if applicable), and user details for every attendance entry.
REQ4: The system must synchronize attendance data across platforms in real time.
REQ5: The system must allow users to view attendance logs and history through the mobile app and web portal.
REQ6: The system must provide administrators with access to edit or override attendance records.
REQ7: The system must offer notifications for missed or late attendance logging via email, SMS, or in-app alerts.
REQ8: The system must generate attendance reports based on various parameters, including user, date range, and department.
REQ9: The system must allow custom scheduling for recurring attendance tasks, such as exams or holidays.
REQ10: The system must enable geofencing for mobile app attendance, ensuring users are within a predefined radius before logging attendance.
REQ11: The system must log failed attempts for attendance entry (e.g., invalid credentials) and alert administrators for potential security issues.
REQ12: The system must comply with data security standards, including encryption and secure authentication protocols.
REQ13: The system must support offline attendance logging on biometric devices and sync data once connectivity is restored.
REQ14: The system must provide advanced reporting features, including trend analysis and visual dashboards.
REQ15: The system must enable automated penalties for late or missed attendance entries based on predefined rules.
This feature allows staff and students to request, track, and manage leave or absences, providing transparency and improving workflow efficiency.
Stimulus: A user submits a leave request via the web portal.
Response: The system validates the request, sends it to the appropriate approver, and updates the leave tracker upon approval.
Stimulus: A student marks themselves as absent for a specific day via the mobile app.
Response: The system records the absence, notifies relevant administrators, and updates attendance logs.
REQ1: The system must allow users to submit leave requests through the mobile app and web portal.
REQ2: The system must enable approvers to review and approve or reject leave requests.
REQ3: The system must automatically update attendance records to reflect approved leaves.
REQ4: The system must send notifications for leave status updates (e.g., approved, rejected).
REQ5: The system must provide a calendar view of scheduled leaves for better planning.
This feature enables seamless integration with third-party systems such as payroll, learning management systems (LMS), and student information systems (SIS).
Stimulus: Attendance data is transferred to a payroll system (e.g., SAP).
Response: The system calculates salary deductions for late or missed attendance as well as bonuses for early arrivals based on predefined rules.
Stimulus: A teacher accesses student attendance data via the LMS.
Response: The system queries the database and provides relevant data for the requested student or class.
REQ1: The system must integrate with third-party payroll systems like SAP and QuickBooks to calculate salary adjustments.
REQ2: The system must provide APIs for integration with LMS and SIS platforms.
REQ3: The system must synchronize data across external systems in real time.
Allows administrators to upload and manage work shifts or class timetables, ensuring proper resource allocation.
Stimulus: An administrator creates a shift schedule for a department.
Response: The system allocates resources and notifies users.
Stimulus: A class timetable is updated.
Response: The system recalculates attendance requirements and alerts stakeholders.
REQ1: The system must allow shift and timetable upload for specific departments or users.
REQ2: The system must notify users of schedule changes in real time.
REQ3: The system must handle overlapping shifts or timetable conflicts.
Provides timely notifications for key events, such as missed attendance, pending leave requests, and system updates.
Stimulus: A user is close to missing the attendance logging deadline.
Response: The system sends an SMS and email reminder.
REQ1: The system must send reminders for attendance logging, pending tasks, and upcoming shifts.
REQ2: The system must allow customization of notification settings.
REQ3: Notifications must support email, SMS, and in-appr messages.

Automated attendance reporting is designed to provide comprehensive, customizable reports for faculty, administrators, and students. This feature reduces the manual effort required to generate summaries, trends, and compliance metrics. Reports can be scheduled or generated on-demand and are formatted for easy analysis or sharing with stakeholders.
Stimulus: Faculty clicks the "Generate Report" button on the dashboard and selects "Daily Summary."
System Response: The system retrieves attendance data for the specified day and compiles it into a tabular format.
Stimulus: Faculty selects "Download" and chooses the preferred format (PDF or Excel).
System Response: The system generates the report in the requested format and prompts the user to download the file.
Stimulus: Administrator configures a recurring monthly report summarizing attendance trends for all departments.
System Response: The system schedules the report generation and sends it automatically to the administrators email on the first day of each month.
Stimulus: A student requests their attendance record for the semester through their profile interface.
System Response: The system filters attendance data for the student, formats it into a user-friendly chart, and displays it on the screen.
Stimulus: The student selects "Export" to save a copy.
System Response: The system generates the report and provides a downloadable link.
REQ1: The system must generate daily, weekly, monthly, and custom reports.
: Reports must be exportable in PDF, CSV, and Excel formats.
: The system must support scheduling of recurring reports for delivery via email to specified users.
: Reports must include visual elements such as graphs and charts for trends, alongside tabular data.
REQ5: The system must allow filtering of reports by parameters such as student ID, department, course, and date range.
REQ6: Real-time data aggregation must ensure that reports include the latest attendance entries without delays.
REQ7: The system must comply with accessibility standards, ensuring reports are usable by individuals with disabilities (e.g., screen reader compatibility).
REQ8: All generated reports must include a timestamp, ensuring traceability and accuracy of the data presented.
REQ9: Administrators should have the ability to set attendance thresholds (e.g., minimum 75% attendance) and generate compliance reports highlighting students who fall below the threshold.
REQ10: Reports must integrate seamlessly with external tools such as Power BI or Google Sheets for advanced analytics.
REQ11: The system must log all report generation activities in an audit trail, ensuring accountability and traceability.
Provides tools for tracking employee and student performance based on attendance and punctuality.
REQ1: The system must calculate attendance scores based on predefined criteria.
REQ2: The system must integrate attendance data with evaluation modules in LMS platforms.
Uses geofencing to restrict attendance logging to specific locations.
REQ1: The system must define geofences for specific locations like classrooms or offices.
REQ2: Attendance logging outside the geofenced area must trigger alerts or be denied.
Introduces gamification to encourage timely attendance, such as rewards for consistent punctuality.
REQ1: The system must award points for punctual attendance.
REQ2: The system must allow users to redeem points for rewards.
Ensures the system is usable by individuals with disabilities, following accessibility standards like WCAG.
REQ1: The system must include screen reader support and keyboard navigation.
REQ2: The system must allow users to adjust font sizes and contrast settings.
Enables institutions to customize the systems appearance and workflows according to their brand and policies.
REQ1: The system must allow customization of colors, logos, and themes.
REQ2: The system must allow administrators to define institution specific policies for attendance.

Biometric attendance integration enhances the accuracy and security of attendance tracking by utilizing fingerprint scanners, facial recognition, or other biometric devices. This feature eliminates proxy attendance and ensures that attendance records are tied directly to the individual. The system seamlessly integrates with biometric hardware to capture, validate, and store attendance data in real time.
Stimulus: A student places their finger on the biometric scanner.
System Response: The device captures the fingerprint and sends the data to the TAMS server for validation.
Stimulus: The system matches the fingerprint against the database.
System Response: If valid, the system marks the student as "Present" and displays a success message on the scanner screen.
Stimulus: A faculty member approaches the camera and allows the system to scan their face.
System Response: The system processes the image and matches it with the stored biometric template.
Stimulus: Upon successful validation, the system records the check-in time and updates the attendance log.
Stimulus: A biometric device fails to capture data due to a hardware issue.
System Response: The system displays an error message and prompts the user to try again.
Stimulus: After three failed attempts, the system allows manual attendance entry by authorized personnel.
System Response: Logs the manual entry and flags it for review by administrators.
REQ1: The system must support integration with multiple biometric devices, including fingerprint scanners and facial recognition cameras.
REQ2: Biometric data capture and validation must not exceed 3 seconds per transaction.
REQ3: The system must ensure secure transmission of biometric data using encryption protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2 or higher).
REQ4: The system must maintain compliance with data protection regulations (e.g., GDPR, NDPR) for biometric data storage and processing.
REQ5: A fallback mechanism must allow manual attendance recording in case of hardware failure, with appropriate logging for review.
REQ6: The system must perform periodic health checks on biometric devices and notify administrators of any hardware issues.
REQ7: Biometric attendance logs must be integrated with the central database in real time, ensuring consistency across all system modules.
REQ8: The system must support mobile biometric attendance for remote locations using portable scanners or device cameras.
REQ9: Biometric templates must be securely stored and accessible only to authorized administrators.
REQ10: The system must provide a detailed audit trail for all biometric transactions, including device ID, user ID, and timestamp.
REQ11: The system must support multiple languages for biometric prompts to enhance usability in diverse user environments.
ACTIVITY DIAGRAM WHICH SHOWS THE FLOW OF ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE SYSTEM
The system must authenticate a user within
of all login attempts under typical load conditions (e.g., up to 100 concurrent users).
Authentication delays beyond 3 seconds will create friction and frustration for users. Quick authentication will ensure users can access their accounts without unnecessary delays.
Ensure user credentials (passwords, multi-factor authentication tokens) are efficiently retrieved. Index critical fields like username and email for fast lookups.
Implement caching for session data and user state to reduce load on the database and speed up repeated login attempts.
Use connection pooling to reduce overhead from repeatedly opening and closing database connections.
Concurrency; Concurrent user capacity in login:
The system must handle up to
without degradation of performance (response time for login must remain below 5 seconds for 90% of requests during peak load).
Systems must support significant concurrent user traffic during events like product launches or high-demand usage periods.
Use load balancers and multiple server instances to distribute user traffic across servers.
strategies (especially in cloud environments) that automatically increase resources as concurrent users rise.
If the user session remains idle for more
, the system must automatically log the user out and prompt for re-authentication.
Session timeout and login prompts must complete within
Session timeouts are a critical security feature to prevent
unauthorized access to an account if the user leaves their session unattended. However, delays in logging out or re-authentication will degrade the user experience.
Use session tokens that can expire after a defined period or idle time. Make sure token validation is fast and does not result in unnecessary delays.
Implement client-side timers to detect inactivity and trigger an alert or re-authentication prompt
over a rolling 12-month period, with no more
Uptime is crucial for user trust and operational continuity. With 99.9% uptime, the system can tolerate brief outages (e.g., maintenance windows) without significantly affecting users.
Design for high availability with redundant systems (e.g., replicated databases, multiple application servers in different availability zones or regions).
Implement comprehensive monitoring to detect failures early, and ensure that automated alerts notify administrators before outages become critical.
The system must be able to
without significant performance degradation or downtime. It should be able to support up to 50% more user traffic in half a year without performance decrease.
The system must be able to accommodate unexpected traffic spikes, such as during marketing campaigns, promotions, or viral events, to ensure that users do not experience slowdowns or downtime.
Implement cloud-based auto-scaling mechanisms to dynamically add new instances during high traffic periods and scale down once the load subsides.
Use load balancing to distribute traffic evenly across available servers, preventing any single server from becoming overwhelmed.

The system must enforce rate limiting of login attempts such that no user or IP address can attempt more than 5 login attempts per minute. If the rate is exceeded, the system should lock the account for 30 minutes or prompt the user for CAPTCHA verification.
To prevent brute-force attacks, the system must limit how many times a user or attacker can attempt to guess login credentials in a given period.
Use IP-based rate limiting to restrict the number of requests a client can make in a given time period. This can be implemented using a reverse proxy like Nginx or a web application firewall.
After a certain number of failed login attempts, introduce a
challenge to distinguish human users from automated bots.

For real-time systems or applications that require immediate processing (e.g., attendance management system, live data monitoring), the processing time should be less than 3 second for 95% of data transactions.
Real-time systems (e.g., attendance system, live chat) require low-latency data processing to ensure that users receive timely updates and can take action accordingly.
(e.g., Redis) or high-performance message queues to minimize data processing times. Also, ensure that long-running operations are offloaded to background jobs rather than blocking the user
Use optimized algorithms and data structures (e.g., hash maps) for quick processing and access to user-specific data.

The system must handle timeouts (such as slow network connections or database issues) within 5 seconds, with an appropriate error message displayed to the user. In case of errors such as; invalid credentials, database failure), the system should return an error message in
and ensure the system is recoverable withi
if critical failure occurs (e.g., authentication service goes down).

The system needs to be resilient to errors, providing quick feedback to users without crashing or freezing. If theres a critical failure (e.g., database or authentication service outage), the system should recover quickly and resume normal operations.

Implement graceful degradation strategies to ensure that minor errors don't lead to system-wide crashes. For example, if a service is unavailable, notify the user of the issue and provide alternatives or retry options.
to ensure that even if one service instance fails, another can take over without impacting user experience. Additionally, use
to avoid unnecessary retries when a service is known to be down.

When developing a Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS), it is crucial to consider various safety and security requirements to mitigate potential loss, damage, or harm that could arise from its use.
