Below are the specified requirements, safeguards, actions to be taken or prevented, and relevant external policies or regulations.
The system must protect sensitive employee data, including
, attendance records, and biometric data (if applicable).
Implement encryption for data at rest and in transit.
Use secure authentication methods (e.g., multi-factor authentication).
Regularly update and patch software to protect against vulnerabilities.
Prevent unauthorized access to the system through role-based access controls.
Avoid storing sensitive data in plain text.

The system must comply with relevant data protection regulations, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in Europe, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) in the U.S. (if applicable), and other local data protection laws.
Conduct regular audits to ensure compliance with applicable regulations.
Implement data retention policies that comply with legal requirements.
Prevent the collection of unnecessary personal data that does not serve a legitimate business purpose.
The user interface must be designed to minimize user error and enhance usability, ensuring that employees can easily and accurately record their attendance.
Conduct usability testing to identify and rectify potential user interface issues.
Provide clear instructions and training for users on how to use the system effectively.
Prevent complex navigation that could lead to user frustration or errors in attendance recording.
The system must be reliable and available to prevent loss of attendance data due to system failures.
Implement regular backups of attendance data to prevent data loss.
Use redundancy and failover mechanisms to ensure system availability.
Prevent single points of failure in the system architecture.
If the system uses biometric data (e.g., fingerprint or facial recognition), it must comply with specific regulations regarding the collection and storage of biometric information.
Ensure biometric data is stored securely and encrypted.
Obtain explicit consent from users before collecting biometric data.
Prevent the sharing of biometric data with third parties without user consent.
Requirement: The system must meet industry standards and safety certifications relevant to software and data security.
Obtain certifications such as ISO/IEC 27001 for information security management.
Ensure compliance with the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) if payment processing is involved.
Prevent the deployment of the system without obtaining necessary certifications.
The system must have an incident response plan in place to address data breaches or security incidents.
Establish a clear protocol for reporting and responding to security incidents.
Train staff on recognizing and reporting potential security threats.
Prevent delays in incident reporting that could exacerbate the impact of a security breach.
All data stored or transmitted by the system must comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) for user data protection and the Nigerian Data Protection Regulation (NDPR).
Sensitive information, including personal details and attendance records, must be encrypted using industry-standard algorithms (e.g., AES-256) during storage and transmission.
The system must anonymize or pseudonymize personally identifiable information (PII) where feasible to reduce exposure risk.
User identity must be verified through multi-factor authentication (MFA) for administrators and staff with elevated privileges.
Students and employees must use strong passwords, adhering to defined password policies, including minimum length, complexity, and expiration intervals.
Biometric authentication (e.g., fingerprint or facial recognition) may be implemented for additional security during clock-in/clock-out procedures.
Role-based access control (RBAC) must be enforced to restrict data access based on user roles and responsibilities.
System administrators must have access to manage permissions, but actions must be logged for auditing purposes.
The product must conform to Nile University's IT Governance policies regarding data confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
Backup and disaster recovery procedures must be implemented, with backups encrypted and tested regularly for integrity.
Adherence to ISO/IEC 27001 standards for Information Security Management Systems (ISMS).
Compliance with relevant labor laws regarding attendance tracking and employee data in Nigeria.
The product should achieve certification or approval from appropriate security auditors to ensure adherence to security policies and privacy regulations.
Maintain detailed audit logs of system activity, including logins, data modifications, and administrative actions. Logs must be tamper-proof and stored securely.
Automated monitoring and alerting systems must be implemented to detect and respond to potential security breaches.
The system must allow for updates to business rules and workflows (e.g., changes in appointment booking logic or attendance thresholds) through configuration files without requiring code changes.
The system must achieve an uptime of 99.9% annually, translating to a maximum allowable downtime of 8.76 hours per year, excluding scheduled maintenance windows.
High Availability (HA) architecture must be implemented using load balancers, redundant server instances, and failover mechanisms.
All algorithms used for calculating attendance, generating schedules, and enforcing business rules must undergo formal verification and unit testing to ensure mathematical accuracy.
A verification mechanism should validate all database operations (e.g., ensuring no duplication of appointments or incorrect attendance entries).
The system should allow administrators to dynamically enable or disable features (e.g., appointment slots, attendance modules) through a centralized admin panel.
Feature toggles must be implemented for quick activation or deactivation of specific functionalities during runtime.
Integration with external systems (e.g., Google Calendar, Outlook, HRIS platforms) must be achieved using RESTful APIs or Webhooks, supporting JSON and XML data formats.
The system must comply with OpenAPI standards and provide comprehensive API documentation.
All source code must adhere to industry standard guidelines, such as PSR12 for PHP or PEP 8 for Python.
The system should achieve a maintainability index of 85 or higher, as measured by tools like SonarQube.
Logging and monitoring must be implemented using tools like ELK Stack or Grafana for real-time visibility into system operations.
The system must be containerized using Docker to ensure consistent deployment across different environments.
Kubernetes (or an equivalent orchestration tool) must be used to manage deployments and scaling.
The system must handle a load of up to 10,000 concurrent users with no more than a 5% degradation in response time.
A comprehensive disaster recovery plan must be in place, including automated failover and data replication mechanisms.
Modules such as authentication, notification services, and reporting must be implemented as independent microservices to promote reuse across multiple projects.
Shared libraries must adhere to semantic versioning and include documentation for integration.
The system must validate all user inputs at both the client and server levels to prevent invalid data entry.
Error handling mechanisms must be implemented to gracefully handle edge cases, with descriptive error messages logged for debugging.
All critical system modules must achieve a minimum of 90% code coverage through automated unit tests.
Integration tests should validate end-to-end workflows, with results stored in a CI/CD pipeline for traceability.
The user interface (UI) must conform to WCAG 2.1 AA standards for accessibility.
Usability testing must confirm that key actions (e.g., booking an appointment or viewing attendance) require no more than 3 clicks and can be completed within 10 seconds.
The system must handle an increasing number of users, including staff, students, visitors, and external entities, without compromising performance or responsiveness.
Robust security measures must be in place, including encryption of all data and clearance-based access controls.
Administrators must manage permissions to protect sensitive attendance records from unauthorized access or modification.
Students: Can perform actions such as viewing attendance, booking appointments, and canceling their bookings.
Teachers: Can mark attendance, approve or reject appointment requests, and access class level reports.
Administrators: Have full access to all system functionalities, including data management, role configuration, and reporting.
Appointments must be booked at least 24 hours in advance to allow scheduling logistics.
A user may have a maximum of 3 active (pending or confirmed) appointments at any given time.
Appointment time slots must be dynamically generated based on staff availability and predefined operating hours.
Attendance records must be updated by teachers within 48 hours of the class session.
Any modification beyond this period requires approval from an administrator, with reasons logged for auditing.
Users must receive real-time notifications for appointment confirmations, cancellations, and attendance updates via email and SMS.
Notifications should be configurable, allowing users to opt-in or out of specific types.
Attendance and appointment data must be retained for a minimum of 5 years to comply with institutional and regulatory policies.
Archived data should be retrievable within 24 hours upon request.
Only designated personnel (e.g., HR, HODs, or level advisers) are allowed to make adjustments to attendance records. Unauthorized changes must be prohibited.
These occurrences must be tracked separately for both staff and students, with notifications sent to relevant supervisors or departments to enforce accountability.
Students can only view their personal attendance records without modification rights.
Staff can access department level data but cannot alter records.
Administrators, particularly in security roles, have full access and control over system data and configurations.
Attendance reports must be secure and tamperproof. Lecturers or staff are not permitted to modify reports to ensure the integrity of attendance data.
Records for external visitors, including government officials or other guests, must be logged accurately and stored securely for institutional tracking purposes
The system shall allow staff and students to register biometric data (e.g., fingerprints).
Ensure compatibility with multiple biometric devices.
The system shall validate attendance using biometric authentication.
Attendance records shall be stored securely in the database.
The system shall generate attendance reports for staff and students.
Reports should be exportable in PDF and Excel.
The system shall provide role-based access for admins, teachers, and students.
Ensure compliance with role-based access control (RBAC).
Biometric devices shall integrate seamlessly with the system.
The system shall log all attendance-related activities for auditing.
Users shall receive alerts for missed attendance or errors in logging.
Email and SMS notifications must be tested.
The system shall operate across multiple platforms (e.g., desktop and mobile).
Ensure responsive design and cross-platform compatibility.
The system shall support backup and recovery of attendance data.
Backup frequency should meet compliance standards.
The system must use a relational database (e.g., PostgreSQL or MySQL) for structured data and a NoSQL database (e.g., MongoDB) for unstructured data such as logs.
All sensitive data, such as user credentials, must be encrypted using AES256 encryption.
Database queries must be optimized to maintain response times under 500ms for complex operations.
The system must comply with GDPR, HIPAA (if applicable), and local data protection laws.
Audit trails must be maintained to log all user actions for at least 5 years.
Core components, such as authentication and notification services, must be developed as standalone microservices for reuse in future projects.
Common utilities (e.g., date pickers, validation libraries) should be packaged as shared libraries with clear API documentation.
Average response times for all critical user actions must not exceed 2 seconds under normal load conditions.
Stress tests must ensure the system can scale to handle 10,000 requests per minute during peak usage.
Full database backups must occur daily, with incremental backups every 4 hours.
Recovery Time Objective (RTO) should not exceed 30 minutes, and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) should not exceed 15 minutes.
Seamless integration with biometric devices, the university student portal, payroll systems, and potentially CCTV systems to enhance accountability and utility.
Compatibility with existing infrastructure to avoid unnecessary replacement costs.
Transition from outdated card systems to biometric scanners.
Ensure compatibility with desktops, laptops, and future ready hardware.
Provide clear and detailed user manuals for all user classes (students, staff, and administrators).
Include online tutorials, FAQs, and QuickStart guides for ease of use.
Offer technical support documentation for IT teams managing the system.
Ensure adherence to local data protection laws, institutional policies, and global standards for privacy and security.
Success of the system will be evaluated through measurable improvements, such as reduced absenteeism, streamlined payroll processing, and enhanced administrative efficiency.
Regular audits should ensure the system meets reliability, security, and scalability expectations
API: Application Programming Interface; a set of protocols for building and interacting with software applications.
CI/CD: Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment; a practice in software development to frequently deliver and test code.
HA: High Availability; system design that ensures a high level of operational performance.
HIPAA: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act; a U.S. regulation for data security and privacy.
RPO: Recovery Point Objective; the maximum tolerable amount of data loss measured in time. RTO: Recovery Time Objective; the target time for restoring services after an outage.
WCAG: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines; standards for making web content accessible to people with disabilities.
System: Refers to the Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS).
User: Includes students, teachers, administrators, or any individual interacting with the system. Attendance Record: A log tracking the presence or absence of students or staff.
TAMS: Time and Attendance Management System
System: Refers to the Time and Attendance Management System (TAMS).
User: Includes students, teachers, administrators, or any individual interacting with the system.
Attendance Record: A log tracking the presence or absence of students or staff.
GDPR: the General Data Protection Regulation
FERPA: the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act

Blue-Green Deployments: In this strategy, you have two identical environments, one live and one in development. You can instantly switch traffic between the two environments, allowing for a seamless transition and zero downtime. If there are issues with the new environment, you can immediately switch back to the live environment.

Canary deployment: In this strategy, you roll out a new release to a small group of users first, called canaries. You monitor the performance and feedback of the canaries, and only roll out the new release to the rest of the system if there are no problems. This strategy allows you to identify and fix issues before they affect the majority of users.
A DFD will be provided to illustrate how data moves between system components, including user interfaces, databases, and external systems.
A UML class diagram will define the relationships between core entities, such as Users, Appointments, Notifications, and Attendance Records.
A state diagram will describe the lifecycle of an appointment, from booking to cancellation or completion.
The ERD will model the database structure, detailing entities, attributes, and relationships.
Appendix C: To Be Determined List
Notification Channels: Determine whether push notifications will be supported in addition to email and SMS.
Data Retention Policy: Confirm if data retention should exceed 5 years for specific use cases.
Integration Systems: Finalize the list of external systems for API integration (e.g., third-party calendar systems).
Accessibility Testing Tools: Select tools for testing compliance with WCAG 2.1 standards
